title: Curvaceous gothic numerals ID, Kanzlei close... but not!
content:
Please ID font, I’m super interested to know what it is.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203233939im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/twentyseven_5356.jpg)

Thanks.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [twentyseven.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203233939/http:/typophile.com/files/twentyseven.jpg) | 27.33 KB |

 [‹ Fokker airplane markings](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203233939/http:/www.typophile.com/node/41661 "Go to previous forum topic") [Looking for a digital version of "Caratteri Franklin" shadow display face ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203233939/http:/www.typophile.com/node/41662 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Quarter

comments.content:
The numerals in Zapf’s old “Firenze” face for ITC were very close to this, esspecially the 2. The sample below is from the Serif Font ID Guide.

- Mike Yanega

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203233939im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/firenze_full_5577.gif)

The only digital version I know is the one from the old Image Club Letterpress 5 or 6 CD (while Image Club was independent, before 1996)

- Mike Yanega

I (like the others, apparently) thought you were way off base with the gothic/Kanzlei angle, Alberta H. Not so, as it turns out. With only your partial 2 and 7 to judge from, your typeface appears to be Steelplate Textura. This was digitiized by [Paul Lloyd](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203233939/http:/www.moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/lloyd/blackjewels/index.htm) as Dampfplatz (A poor job. I mention it only because it offers shaded/inline fonts as well) and [Dieter Steffmann](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203233939/http:/www.moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/steffmann/samples/s/steelplate.htm) (a _much_ better version).
